This is Bill Vernon. And Darrell Ng. Science fiction writer George R. R. Martin recently hit his third novel, Fever Dream, published in Hardcover by Poseidon Press. Fever Dream is a science fictional historical horror novel, which combines the vampire legend and Mississippi Riverboats in the anti-Belom South. I'd read other people's vampire novels, or as Dracula, and the other books, to other recent ones. And I had wanted to do my own version of that legend, um, time because I had a few ideas about it. But I didn't want it to be just another Dracula book, just another rehash of the same old legend. Because we've seen vampire books after vampire books, essentially just the same thing. It's been over and over again. I think that's what it's tiresome. And at the same time, I was going through all these thoughts about vampires with periods that I was living in the Bugaiowa. I taught college there for three years, and the beautiful courses, the Rivertown, it was once a big steamboat manufacturing center, and it's still very much a view of it, the old history of the right arrow steam on the Mississippi. So it was during that period, while I was in the Bugaiowa, I got interested in the that period of history I get interested in the steamboat. I read a fair amount about them. And once I did the two things just seem to come together in my mind, there's a certain romanticism, I think, a dark romanticism that's linked to both the old steamboats and vampires. They're both very attractive in a certain sense. The elegant vampire and the state-leaf, intricate gorgeous steamboat. But they also have dark sides too, for me.
